And they also spent up to $10 million funding most of the major think tanks that research and write about policy solutions about nuclear weapons,â€ wrote ICAN.Read moreMoscow responds to idea of sending nukes to UkraineThe report goes on to note that all this spending has done nothing to deter any sort of conflict and that recent geopolitical events in Europe have only served to further line the pockets of those who are tied to the nuclear weapons industry.â€œWe were told that the billions invested in thousands of weapons of mass destruction with the power to destroy the world many times over was the price to pay for peace in Europe. Instead, those billions went to line the pockets of the powerful who profit from the production of weapons of mass destruction.â€The authors stress that the report demonstrates that â€œnuclear weapons donâ€™t workâ€ as they have failed to deter conflict in Europe.â€œThis is why we need multilateral disarmament more than ever. The first meeting of states parties to the Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons in Vienna [from June 21 to 23] could not come at a better time," ICAN Policy and Research Coordinator Alicia Sanders-Zakre said.ICAN is a Nobel Peace Prize-winning, Geneva-based international coalition that has been actively campaigning for the respect and full implementation of the Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons which it helped adopt at the UN in 2017. The treaty has been ratified by 59 countries around the world so far, however not a single nuclear state has yet to sign it.

title: Reality trumps principles as Biden plans a meeting with the Saudi crown prince â€” RT World News
article: Reality trumps principles as Biden plans a meeting with the Saudi crown prince                        Bidenâ€™s first trip to the Middle East looks set to highlight the consistent inconsistency of his administrationâ€™s foreign policy            Bradley Blankenship is an American journalist,columnist and political commentator. He has a syndicated column at CGTN and is a freelance reporter for international news agencies including Xinhua News Agency.Bradley Blankenship is an American journalist,columnist and political commentator. He has a syndicated column at CGTN and is a freelance reporter for international news agencies including Xinhua News Agency.@BradBlank_FILE - President Joe Biden speaks during a bill signing ceremony, June 13, 2022, in the East Room of the White House in Washington. Biden will make his first trip to the Middle East next month with visits to Israel, the West Bank and Saudi Arabia. Â©                AP PhotoPatrick Semansky, FileAmid record gas prices in the United States, the administration of President Joe Biden announced that he will visit Saudi Arabia during his first Middle East trip as president. Bidenâ€™s decision to visit the kingdom, which is perennially accused of human rights violations, shows the inherent contradictions that drive the administrationâ€™s foreign policy.Bidenâ€™s foreign policy has two fundamental pillars, at least in terms of messaging. The first is that US foreign policy should puthuman rights at the center while the other is that US diplomatic relations should help average Americans, claiming to meld foreign and domestic policies. The application of these two has proven extremely challenging, which could be described as consistently inconsistent.The trip to Saudi Arabia aims to reduce average Americansâ€™ prices at the pump. That is clear. But itâ€™s hard to square this circle when Biden had previously saidhe would not speak with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, the kingdomâ€™s foremost power player â€“but now says he will meet with him under these circumstances, though, he claims, not one-on-one.Read moreBiden should â€˜shunâ€™ Saudi prince â€“ congressmanThe prince, who goes by MBS, is credibly accused of being behind the brutal murder of Jamal Khashoggi, a Saudi-born US resident and Washington Post columnist who was dismembered in the Saudi embassy in Istanbul, Turkey. MBS is also believed to be the main orchestrator of the Saudi-led war on Yemen, which has featured one of the most brutal and indiscriminate bombing campaigns in memory.Itâ€™s hard to see how Biden can claim to be putting human rights at the center of his agenda while meeting with the likes of MBS. This after his administration just wrapped up the latest Summit of the Americas, which excluded the governments of Cuba, Nicaragua and Venezuela based on human rights concerns, while also including such countries as Colombia and Brazil â€“ bastions of human rights, no doubt.Speaking of Venezuela, while the US considers it a violator of human rights and democratic norms, and also doesnâ€™t even recognize Nicolas Maduro as the legitimate president, Washington has started to ease sanctions on Venezuela and even held high-level meetings with the government in Caracas. For example, Washington is reportedly planning to allow Venezuela to ship oil to Europe to plug up holes left by the exclusion of Russian crude.We can see that US foreign policy is consistently inconsistent, mostly in that it tries to remain true to certain principles but immediately betrays them when reality sets in. It shows that the proclaimed US ideals are out of touch with geopolitical realities, and would inevitably hurt average Americans if actually implemented to their logical conclusion.At the same time, however, itâ€™s debatable to what extent helping average Americans is even one of the main priorities of Bidenâ€™s foreign policy. In the Middle East, for example, the Biden administration is sacrificing progress made on the implementation of the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA, or the Iran nuclear deal) in pursuit of its most recent Middle East peace plan.Read moreUS-Saudi relations nearing â€˜breaking pointâ€™ â€“ mediaBut the details of this plan reveal that there is certainly nothing peaceful about it. On June 9, Congress introduced bipartisan legislation that would see the Pentagon coordinate air defenses with Israel and a number of Arab states against Iran. It will also see tons of weapons funneled into the region â€“ in spite of the fact that a March report by the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute showed weapons imports beginning to level off.It is hard to see how throwing a wrench into a process that would help halt nuclear proliferation in the Middle East, opting instead to just funnel weapons into the region and whip up an anti-Iran military alliance, actually helps the American people. On the contrary, it seems to only be beneficial to military contractors that inherently profit from destabilization and catastrophe.Bidenâ€™s foreign policy is consistently inconsistent. The administration claims to follow certain principles and norms, like human rights, yet abandons them when the political fallout would be too great. Itâ€™s clear this is the case, as Bidenâ€™s Democratic Party faces a stiff challenge from Republicans in this yearâ€™s midterm elections â€“ all while the US economy is facing record inflation and a looming recession.The statements, views and opinions expressed in this column are solely those of the author and do not necessarily represent those of RT.oped

title: 19 years on from the US invasion of Iraq, has the West learned any lessons? â€” RT World News
article: 19 years on from the US invasion of Iraq, has the West learned any lessons?                        Almost two decades and an estimated million deaths later, the media is once again beating the drums of war            Robert Inlakesh isa political analyst, journalist and documentary filmmaker currently based in London, UK. He has reported from and lived in the Palestinian territories and currently works with Quds News. Director of â€˜Steal of the Century: Trump's Palestine-Israel Catastropheâ€™.Robert Inlakesh isa political analyst, journalist and documentary filmmaker currently based in London, UK. He has reported from and lived in the Palestinian territories and currently works with Quds News. Director of â€˜Steal of the Century: Trump's Palestine-Israel Catastropheâ€™.@falasteen47Airstrikes target Islamic State positions in Mosul, Iraq, July 11, 2017 Â©                (AP PhotoFelipe Dana, File)The US-led invasion of Iraq in March, 2003 was a war now accepted to have been built on lies and is said to have killed as many as one million Iraqis. However, despite the horrific bloodshed inflicted on the Iraqi people, the Western public seem to have forgotten so many of the lessons that should have been taken away from the disaster that was the Iraq War.In the build-up to the war on Iraq, Americans were told that eliminating Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, was necessary for world peace. This was due to his alleged possession of Weapons of Mass Destruction (WMD) as well as his alleged links with Al-Qaeda, among a number of other claims about Husseinâ€™s genocidal ambitions. Britainâ€™s then-prime minister, Tony Blair, even likened Saddam Hussein to Adolf Hitler; this was at a time when anti-Middle Eastern sentiment was high and the 911 attacks were ripe in the minds of the Western public, who had been informed by then-US President George W. Bush that the â€˜war on terrorâ€™ was akin to aâ€˜crusadeâ€™.It turned out that almost none of the major allegations about Saddam Hussein were true, despite the Iraqi presidentâ€™s other crimes against humanity. Yet,with no evidence, Western media fell in line and presented the invasion of Iraq as a just war, despite the International Commission of Jurists (ICJ) in Geneva stating that it constituted a war of aggression and a flagrant violation of international law prior to the invasion occurring.Read moreIran claims responsibility for missile attack â€“ reportsLikely due in large part to the media coverage at the time, which had demonized everything Middle Eastern and Muslim, US public support for invading Iraq prior to â€˜Operation Iraqi Liberationâ€™ was between 52-64%, jumping up to 72% support on invasion day.In the first two months of the â€˜Shock and Aweâ€™ invasion of Iraq, more than 7,186 Iraqi civilians were said to have been killed. Yet, at the time, Western media outlets were celebrating the US-UK victory as if none of this death and destruction had taken place, never truly asking where the alleged WMD were. A BBC reporter, Andrew Marr,said on April 9 of British PM Tony Blair that â€œHe said they would be able to take Baghdad without a bloodbath and in the end the Iraqis would be celebrating. And on both of those points he has been proven conclusively right.â€The blindly pro-US-UK government coverage went on, despite reports of US and UK war crimes. For example, on April 2, 2003, US aircraft struck a Red Crescent maternity hospital in Baghdad, resulting in a massacre according to The Guardian.Within less than two years of the invasion, it is said that as many as 100,000 innocent Iraqi civilians were killed, yet George W. Bush still managed to get re-elected in 2004. This was with the United Nations Security Council (UNSC) not granting permission for the invasion, countless reports of civilian targets being hit, and calls from anti-war voices for the prosecution of Bush and Blair for war crimes.On October 6, 2003, Time Magazine was still running cover for the Bush administration, only offering small criticisms of how President Bush miscalculatedâ€œfixing Iraq,â€ whilst The Economist went with a headline in May that read:â€˜Now, the waging of peaceâ€™, which was endorsing the idea of nation-building in Iraq and ignoring the alleged war crimes.Eventually, all the major news outlets in the West, including the likes of CNN, BBC, Fox News, and others, bowed their heads in shame of theirone-sided reporting on what had occurred in Iraq and what Noam Chomsky called their participation in â€˜manufacturing consentâ€™.Read moreMultiple rockets land near US consulate in Iraq â€“ reportsPeter Van Buren, a former US State Department official based in Iraq for a year, was asked about whether the Western media had learnt its lesson from Iraq andsaid the following:â€œLessons learned? No. La [â€˜noâ€™ in Arabic]. Nyet [â€˜noâ€™ in Russian]. As a State Department officer in 2003, I watched in horror as the mainstream press acted not only as stenographers for government lies but amplifiers of those lies, employing anonymous sources at the expense of their own credibility to create and then service a narrative demanding war. When their true editor-in-chief, George W. Bush, stood up, a mix of Ben Bradley and Lou Grant, to proclaim â€˜you were either with us or with the terrorists,â€™ the media stifled dissent in their ranks nearly completely. In 2022, little has changed. The media again beats the drum for war, albeit this time as stenographers for the Ukrainian governmentâ€™s propaganda. Almost all of the video and imagery out of Ukraine comes from their government and those anonymous sources of 2003 have been replaced by no real sourcing at all. Crushing dissent has caught up with the times, so voices for restraint are not just left off the New York Times op-ed page, they are canceled, deplatformed, and sent down the social media memory hole, unemployable as Putin-lovers.â€Today, the crimes committed in Iraq are well known to the Western public, yet the former leaders of the United States and United Kingdom have never faced consequences for the chaos they caused. Not only has the war left Iraq divided, in terms of de-jure and societal ethno-religious division, but US forces are still stationed in Iraq in their thousands. NATO even announced early last year that they were expanding their own mission to 4,000 personnelin Iraq.In addition to this, Iraq has faced the rise and fall of ISIS, a sectarian Sunni-Shia war, US occupation, torture centers, and chemical weapon deployment against civilians, and this has stained the new collective memory of the new generation of Iraqis. The young generation of Iraqis now also face a corrupt Iraqi elite, installed into a confessionalist [sectarian] system of government, which has largely been based on a manufactured political culture of nepotism.Read moreProtesters mourn assassinated general by burning US flagsHas the US even been able to claim victory in Iraq after 19 years of destruction? Absolutely not. Washington is still battling to hold enough power in the country in order to combat the role of neighboring Iran, which jumped in to fill the power vacuum with its allied forces who were established to fight ISIS and Al-Qaeda.Prior to the removal of Saddam Hussein, Iraq was not a country divided on sectarian lines and did not have a problem with Al-Qaeda or other terrorist groups. The country has been torn apart since 2003 and the same media organizations which religiously took the side of Western governments are today working as the same propaganda machines. The active undermining of the Iraqi experience of war, with countless Western journalists saying things like, we should care more because the bombs are dropping on â€œrelatively civilisedâ€ people, can be put down to racism, and it is this sort of dangerous rhetoric which enables Western audiences to ignore the alleged 6 million victims of the failed â€˜war on terrorâ€™. Until the perpetrators of the Iraq War are brought to justice, the US government cannot claim the moral high ground over its adversaries, and its position on the world stage shall forever be tainted.The statements, views and opinions expressed in this column are solely those of the author and do not necessarily represent those of RT.oped

title: US-led human rights resolution against China could backfire â€” RT World News
article: US-led human rights resolution against China could backfire                        Washingtonâ€™s resolution against China at the UNâ€™s rights body is bound to be embarrassing            Bradley Blankenship is an American journalist,columnist and political commentator. He has a syndicated column at CGTN and is a freelance reporter for international news agencies including Xinhua News Agency.Bradley Blankenship is an American journalist,columnist and political commentator. He has a syndicated column at CGTN and is a freelance reporter for international news agencies including Xinhua News Agency.@BradBlank_Â©                AP PhotoCliff OwenThe United States called on the United Nations Human Rights Council (UNHRC) on September 26 to discuss alleged human rights violations in Chinaâ€™s Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region. Washingtonâ€™s request comes after a recent UN reportthat warned of possible crimes against humanity in the Chinese territory.The resolution brought forth by the US was also co-sponsored by the United Kingdom, Canada, Sweden, Denmark, Finland, Iceland and Norway. The 47-member UNHRC will vote on the resolution this week, with Western countries apparently afraid that it might not pass. If it does, a debate on the issue will be scheduled for the council's next session in February.Indeed, a joint statement delivered by Pakistan on behalf of 68 states during the 51st session of the UNHRC called out Western countries for having double standards on the issue of human rights and stressed that Xinjiang, Hong Kong and Tibet-related issues were strictly Chinaâ€™s internal affairs.Looking at the list of current council members, it appears at first glance that China has more support than the West, and 16 of these countries signed onto the aforementioned statement. So the likelihood of the US resolution being tossed out is quite high. Itâ€™s also important to note how mild the action from Washington was, given the fact that it probably knew anything more than a â€œdiscussionâ€ would surely have zero chance of passing.Read moreUN report accuses China of â€˜crimes against humanityâ€™While the prospects of this not passing are already embarrassing enough for Washington and represents a tidal shift in global power, in a way it would almost be less embarrassing. Thatâ€™s because opening up a discussion on human rights would not bode well for Uncle Sam.If we just look at the accusations commonly leveled against China in Xinjiang, such concerns as â€œforced laborâ€, â€œforced disappearances,â€ and infringements on other rights found in the UN report are commonplace in the US. Letâ€™s take a look at some examples.Starting with â€œreligious, cultural and linguistic identity and expression,â€ itâ€™s quite obvious that a country that committed one of the worst genocides in human history, the US, ought to keep its mouth shut on this. But we should note that Washingtonâ€™s genocide against the Native population and its suppression of Native identity is ongoing.Take for instance a widely reported incident involving a Native American man, Darrell House, who was at his peopleâ€™s ancestral lands and got tased by a federal government agent while praying. Of course, the parks service said at the time that it was â€œreviewingâ€ the incident â€“ but such instances happen all the time. In fact, Native Americans are at the center of constitutional law debates time and time again mainly over their religious practices.Moving on to the â€œrights to privacy and freedom of movement,â€ again, we can see that the US routinely violates this. As we learned with the leaksfrom National Security Agency (NSA) whistleblower Edward Snowden, the US operates the world's largest global spy network in the world and collects bulk data on its own citizens without their consent.Read moreChina rebukes US as â€˜worldâ€™s biggest human rights violatorâ€™As for freedom of movement, the case of human rights lawyer Steven Donziger is notable. He won a lawsuit where he represented Ecuadoreans against oil giant Chevron for polluting their country. Then the company fought the ruling, never paid a cent in restitution and lobbied the federal government to pursue trumped up racketeering charges against Donziger. He was under house arrest for more than two years.â€œReproductive rightsâ€ have been all over the news in the States after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, which had established a womanâ€™s constitutional right to an abortion. Now womenâ€™s rights are under serious threat across the country as states begin implementing punitive anti-abortion laws.â€œEmployment and labor issuesâ€ is interesting given the fact that it is widely known that, as of last year, a full-time job in the US at the federal minimum wage of $7.25 canâ€™t pay the rent anywhere in the country. Workplaces are also extremely unsafe, which is evident by the prevalence of Covid-19 in the country. The ongoing pandemic is, more than anything, a workplace safety issue â€“ and the federal government allowed itself to be influenced by employers to undermine workersâ€™ safety.Of course, thereâ€™s no one more exploited than prisoners because the US still allows for slavery as a form of punishment in its constitution. A June report from the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) found that incarcerated workers in the US earn an average wage of between 13 to 52 cents per hour â€“ despite producing nearly $11 billion worth of goods and services annually.Read moreChina, India and Brazil abstain in vote on US resolution, Russia vetoesThatâ€™s, of course, well below the minimum wage â€“ and the state can take up to 80% of this already measly pay for room and board, court costs, restitution and other fees, ironically such as prison maintenance and construction. Almost 70% of prisoners polled said they canâ€™t afford basic necessities â€“ and, damningly, 76% said â€œthey are required to work or face additional punishments such as solitary confinement, denial of opportunities to reduce their sentence, and loss of family visitation.â€On â€œissues of family separation and reprisals,â€ of course most people are familiar with the terrible stories of â€œkids in cagesâ€ at US migrant detention camps. The US routinely separates migrant families at its border â€“ and, according to internal documents seen by The Intercept, its federal agents have at least discussed reprisal against pro-immigrant activists.With the issue of â€œenforced disappearances,â€ the US government notably runs a camp at Guantanamo Bay on the island of Cuba dedicated to literally just that. It has detained 780 people there since 2002 â€“ and many of them without any formal criminal proceedings. The torture techniques used there have included psychological abuse and threats to harm the families of detainees, which certainly falls under the category of â€œintimidations, threats and reprisals.â€That covers every single accusation in the UN report, showing just how hypocritical Washington would be on this issue if it really decided to open a debate at the UNHRC. We can see that with the most minimal effort, China and other countries could rip Uncle Samâ€™s moral superiority to shreds.The statements, views and opinions expressed in this column are solely those of the author and do not necessarily represent those of RT.oped

title: Pharma regulator objects to â€˜Red Light Districtâ€™ â€” RT World News
article: Pharma regulator objects to â€˜Red Light Districtâ€™                        The European Medicines Agency (EMA) is opposing plans to move nearly 100 of Amsterdamâ€™s brothels to a center near its HQ            The Wallen, famous red light district in Amsterdam is preparing for the opening as sex workers get back to work in 2020  Â©Getty Images                  Robin UtrechtSOPA ImagesLightRocket via Getty ImagesEuropeâ€™s pharmaceutical regulator, the European Medicines Agency (EMA), says it has concerns about potential â€œdisorderly behaviorâ€ in the vicinity of its Amsterdam headquarters if the Dutch city follows through with plans to build an â€˜erotic centerâ€™ nearby.In 2021, Amsterdam Mayor Femke Halsema rubber-stamped plans to relocate 100 of the 249 brothels in the cityâ€™s Red Light District to a purpose-built, multi-story center designed to house erotic entertainment and legalized prostitution.The project, which could potentially be built on lands in the cityâ€™s southern Zuidas district, was proposed to help combat rising crime and public overcrowding in the historic center.However, the EMA, which moved to the Dutch capital in 2019 after the United Kingdom exited the EU, says itâ€™s concerned by the possible implications of any such relocation.Read moreAmsterdamâ€™s Red Light District cracks down on cannabisâ€œLocating the Erotic Center in close proximity to EMAâ€™s building is likely to bring the same negative impacts to the adjacent area,â€ the agency said in a statement on Tuesday, adding that it had concerns in relation to â€œnuisance, drug-dealing, drunkenness and disorderly behavior.â€The EMA â€“ which among other things regulates Viagra in Europe â€“ also noted that it welcomes a large number of international delegates to its premises, many of whom often leave â€œlate in the evening,â€ suggesting that it would be concerned for their safety if the plan goes ahead.Safety and security were key considerations when it chose the location for its current headquarters, the agency added.Haselma, however, has said the plan to relocate the Red Light District had been made to help protect sex workers, and to provide a location in which there is less organized crime.â€œI hope itâ€™s possible to create an erotic center that has some class and distinction and isnâ€™t a place where only petty criminals and the most vulnerable women gather,â€ she told The Observer last year. Haselma also conceded that she was aware that many Amsterdam residents wouldnâ€™t want the center to be built near their homes.The proposal remains under public consultation in Amsterdam, with a final decision on the location expected in late 2023.

title: Muskâ€™s ventures at risk of government probe â€“ Bloomberg â€” RT World News
article: Muskâ€™s ventures at risk of government probe â€“ Bloomberg                        The billionaire has reportedly angered US officials with his remarks about Ukraine            FILE PHOTO. Image of Elon Musk displayed next to the logo of Twitter. Â©                Muhammed Selim Korkutata  Anadolu AgencyElon Musk may face a federal investigation in the US, after making officials â€œuncomfortableâ€ with his remarks about Ukraine, Bloomberg has claimed, citing anonymous sources in the government.Persons within the US government and intelligence community are â€œweighing what tools, if anyâ€ are available to target the billionaire, the Friday report said. These discussions were described as being â€œat an early stage.â€One of the options, according to Bloomberg, is to subject Muskâ€™s business ventures to a review by the interagency Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS). The body can reject investment deals involving foreign capital based on national-security considerations.Musk has recently made US officials â€œuncomfortable,â€ Bloomberg reported, with his complaints about not being compensated for the services that his firm SpaceX rendered to the Ukrainian government.Read moreMusk makes U-turn on Starlink for UkraineThe company provides Starlink satellite broadband access to Ukrainian government departments and military to ensure stable communications. This was credited as being a game-changer for the country in its fight against Russia. Musk, who claimed to have spent some $80 million on free equipment and services, threatened to shut down access unless it is paid-for by someone else.He also made a number of suggestions about resolving the Ukraine crisis that went against Washingtonâ€™s goal of â€œdefeating Russiaâ€ strategically. Kiev blasted Muskâ€™s proposals of making concessions to Moscow in the name of peace, with one Ukrainian diplomat suggesting that the SpaceX CEO should â€œf*ck off.â€Musk indicated that he was following that advice with his demands over Starlink compensation, but later backed down and agreed to keep the service open.Bloomberg sources suggested that the main target of a security review, if one is launched, would be Muskâ€™s proposed acquisition of Twitter. He received support from Saudi Arabiaâ€™s Kingdom Holding Company and Qatarâ€™s sovereign wealth fund, in his buyout bid.:    Musk explains withdrawal of free Starlink service for UkraineCrypto exchange Binance, which is run by Chinese-Canadian businessman Changpeng Zhao, is another investor that may be perceived as problematic, the report said.

title: UK PM responds to death of Queen Elizabeth II â€” RT World News
article: UK PM responds to death of Queen Elizabeth II                        The late Queen served with â€œdignity and graceâ€ for 70 years, Liz Truss said            Â© Getty Images  Dan Kitwood British Prime Minister Liz Truss has paid tribute to Queen Elizabeth II, hailing her â€œgreat legacyâ€ and lamenting her passing as â€‹â€‹"a day of great lossâ€ for the United Kingdom and the world.Speaking outside Number 10 Downing Street, Truss said Elizabeth had been â€œthe very spirit of Great Britain,â€ having served â€œwith dignity and graceâ€ for 70 years.Elizabethâ€™s death was announced by the palace at 6:30pm on Thursday evening, with a short statement saying she â€œdied peacefully at Balmoralâ€ earlier in the afternoon. Elizabethâ€™s son Charles, former Prince of Wales, immediately succeeded her to become King of England."Through thick and thin, she provided us with the stability and strength that we needed,â€ Truss said, adding that she was â€œloved and admired by the people in the United Kingdom and all around the world.â€Read moreQueen Elizabeth II dies aged 96 after seven-decade reignShe described the late monarchâ€™s death as â€œthe passing of the second Elizabethan age."Truss said Britons must come together to offer Elizabethâ€™s son, King Charles, â€œloyalty and devotionâ€ to help him bear the massive responsibility that comes with the throne, as a â€œnew era in the magnificent historyâ€ of the nation is ushered in.With the royal family now entering a period of mourning, official engagements are canceled and union flags will be flown at royal residences and government buildings.The late Queenâ€™s last official act was to appoint Truss as prime minister, which she did at Balmoral on Tuesday. Truss became the 15th prime minister to serve under Elizabethâ€™s 70-year reign.Truss concluded her speech with the words â€œGod save the King.â€:    Charles III becomes new British monarch

title: Biden snubs Johnson in UK comments â€” RT World News
article: Biden snubs Johnson in UK comments                        US President made no mention of the British PMâ€™s name in a statement praising alliance with London            FILE PHOTO Â©                Jonathan Ernst  Pool Photo via APThe White House on Thursday issued a statement about the importance of the US-UK alliance in supporting Ukraine, in response to news from London that Prime Minister Boris Johnson had resigned as leader of the Conservative party and would vacate 10 Downing Street once his replacement was named. President Joe Biden did not even mention Johnson by name.â€œThe United Kingdom and the United States are the closest of friends and Allies, and the special relationship between our people remains strong and enduring,â€ said the statement, first published by CBS News.â€œI look forward to continuing our close cooperation with the government of the United Kingdom, as well as our Allies and partners around the world, on a range of important priorities. That includes maintaining a strong and united approach to supporting the people of Ukraine as they defend themselves against [Russian President Vladimir] Putinâ€™s brutal war on their democracy, and holding Russia accountable for its actions,â€ said the statement, attributed to Biden. As of 6pm on Thursday, it had not been posted to the White House website.Biden himself told CNN that he had no further comment on Johnsonâ€™s resignation, when asked about it following the Presidential Medal of Freedom ceremony on Thursday afternoon.â€œNo, itâ€™s a part of the process,â€ said the US leader.: Ukraine saddened by Boris Johnsonâ€™s downfall, Zelensky claimsThe New York Post called Bidenâ€™s statement a â€œsnubâ€ of Johnson, pointing out that previous US presidents traditionally commented on the resignations of British prime ministersâ€™ with a kind word for them personally.Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, by contrast, said all his countrymen were â€œsaddenedâ€ by the news of â€œfriend Boris Johnsonâ€ resigning as the party leader, while also thanking the UK for its help and support.Johnson led the Tories to a historic election victory in 2019 and successfully took the UK out of the EU. Amid the rising cost of living and historic inflation, the party turned on him last month, ostensibly over the Partygate scandal involving violations of Covid-19 lockdowns.While Johnson easily survived the June 6 no-confidence vote, he gave in on Thursday after more than 50 government officials, including cabinet ministers, resigned on him. He will remain the caretaker PM until the Tories can name a replacement.

title: Possible reason for speedy transmission of monkeypox revealed â€” RT World News
article: Possible reason for speedy transmission of monkeypox revealed                        Portuguese researchers discovered 50 mutations of the virus which could explain its spread among humans            Â©Getty Images                  NurPhoto  ContributorThe monkeypox virus mutates much faster than expected when transmitted among humans, new research suggests, providing a possible explanation for the rapid spread of the disease.In a study published in Nature Medicine on Friday, Portuguese researchers reported the results of â€œrapid application of high-throughput shotgun metagenomicsâ€ as they began reconstructing the first genome sequences of the 2022 â€˜versionâ€™ of the monkeypox virus.They discovered that the 2022 virus differs from the related 2018-19 viruses by 50 SNP mutations, which are changes that occur in a single nucleotide in the genome. This is roughly six to 12 times more â€œthan one would expect considering previous estimates of the substitution rate for orthopoxviruses (one or two substitutions per site per year).â€â€œSuch a divergent branch might represent accelerated evolution,â€ the researchers claim. They noted, however, that further studies on the matter are needed.â€œConsidering that this 2022 monkeypox virus is likely a descendant of the one in the 2017 Nigeria outbreak, one would expect no more than five to 10 additional mutations instead of the observed about 50 mutations. We hope that now, specialized groups will perform laboratory experiments in order to understand if this 2022 virus has increased its transmissibility,â€ one of the studyâ€™s authors, head of the Genomics & Bioinformatics Unit at the National Institute of Health in Portugal, Joao Paulo Gomes, told Newsweek.: Monkeypox to be rebranded â€“ WHOThe news came as the World Health Organization considers whether the virus outbreak should be classed as a public health emergency of international concern.According to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, as of June 23, 3,504 cases of monkeypox have been registered in 44 countries with the biggest number reported in the United Kingdom (793 cases).With the disease spreading predominantly among gay men, the Ğ¡DĞ¡ has cautioned doctors not to mistake it for more common sexually transmitted diseases.The WHO is not currently recommending mass vaccination against monkeypox. However, on June 21, the UK Health Security Agency announced that â€œsome gay and bisexual men at higher risk of exposure to monkeypox should be offered vaccines to help control the recent outbreak of the virus.â€The initial symptoms of monkeypox include fever, headache, muscle aches, backache, swollen lymph nodes, chills, and exhaustion. A rash often begins on the face and then spreads to other parts of the body, although the WHO has noted that patients affected by the current outbreak are developing lesions on the genitals and anus, and not developing some of the traditional flu-like symptoms of infection.The virus can be spread by close contact with lesions, body fluids, respiratory droplets, as well as via contaminated materials.

title: Yemen crisis looms over Bidenâ€™s Saudi visit â€” RT World News
article: Yemen crisis looms over Bidenâ€™s Saudi visit                        Government report says Washington turned a blind eye to suffering caused by US weapons            People gather after an explosion in the city of Lawdar in Yemen's southern province of Abyan on July 5, 2022. Â© AFP US President Joe Biden claimed credit for the ceasefire in Yemen in a weekend op-ed defending his upcoming trip to Saudi Arabia. He did not comment on the recent report by the government watchdog GAO, which said that the State Department and the Pentagon stopped holding Riyadh accountable for how it used the US-supplied weapons against civilians, a prominent critic pointed out on Monday.Biden had promised to â€œcompletely disengageâ€ the US from the Saudi-led war on Yemen, but failed to do so, argued Juan Cole, professor of Middle Eastern and South Asian history at the University of Michigan.The US has provided $54.6 billion in military aid to Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates (UAE) since they began bombing Yemen in March 2015, Cole pointed out. US law requires recipients of American military aid to avoid harming civilian non-combatants, but Cole said the Saudi-led coalition has flouted that requirement â€“ and pointed to last monthâ€™s report by the Government Accountability Office (GAO) showing that the US government did not bother enforcing it, either.The State Department certified in 2018 that the Saudi and Emirati governments â€œhad made efforts to reduce harm to civilians in Yemen, but did not submit two subsequent, required certifications,â€ said the GAO. Foggy Bottom also â€œcould not provideâ€ evidence that they investigated â€œincidents of potential unauthorized use of equipmentâ€ transferred to Saudi Arabia or the UAE, while the Pentagon â€œhas not reportedâ€ any investigations, the watchdog added.: Biden attempts to justify Saudi Arabia tripBiden is headed to Saudi Arabia and Israel later this week. In a Washington Post op-ed on Saturday, he tried to preempt critics by saying he wanted to â€œreorient â€“ but not rupture â€“ relationsâ€ with the Kingdom. Among other things, Biden credited â€œour persistent diplomacyâ€ with the current truce in Yemen leading, which he said the Saudis fully support.Neither Saudi Arabia nor the Houthi rebels in Yemen credited Washington with the ceasefire that first went into effect at the end of March. It has since been extended through at least early August, though both sides have accused the other of not fully abiding by its terms.In April, the Wall Street Journal reported that US-Saudi relations were at their worst since 1945, citing the Biden administrationâ€™s personal criticism of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman over the 2018 killing of dissident Jamal Khashoggi.Last week, the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) released a report on the humanitarian situation in Yemen, with its author Basheer Omar calling it â€œunimaginable horror.â€ Two thirds of Yemenâ€™s estimated 30.5 million people lacked access to basic healthcare and more than four million have been displaced by the fighting, the report said.: Yemeni mothers and babies facing â€˜unimaginable horror,â€™ Red Cross tells RTAccording to the UN, Yemen is the â€œworldâ€™s worst humanitarian crisis,â€ which resulted in over 377,000 deaths by the end of 2021. More than two-thirds of the casualties were under the age of five.While Biden himself used the UN phrasing in his oped, he has not spoken up in support of a bipartisan initiative in Congress to stop further US support to Riyadh â€“ not just in terms of weapons but intelligence and maintenance support â€“ and thereby compel the end to the war.

title: Biden pledged to end the war in Yemen, but is doing the opposite â€” RT World News
article: Biden pledged to end the war in Yemen, but is doing the opposite                        The US is being accused of getting in the way of UN efforts to negotiate a truce between Yemenâ€™s Ansarallah and the Saudi-led coalition            Robert Inlakesh isa political analyst, journalist and documentary filmmaker currently based in London, UK. He has reported from and lived in the Palestinian territories and currently works with Quds News. Director of â€˜Steal of the Century: Trump's Palestine-Israel Catastropheâ€™.Robert Inlakesh isa political analyst, journalist and documentary filmmaker currently based in London, UK. He has reported from and lived in the Palestinian territories and currently works with Quds News. Director of â€˜Steal of the Century: Trump's Palestine-Israel Catastropheâ€™.@falasteen47FILE - A Yemeni soldier inspects a site of Saudi-led airstrikes targeting two houses in Sanaa, Yemen, March 26, 2022. Â©                AP PhotoHani Mohammed, FileTwo weeks into his term, US President Joe Biden claimed that he would seek a negotiated peace in Yemen, thus shunning Saudi Arabia. Now he is performing a 180-degree pivot. With such arbitrary foreign policy positions the US is causing instability and weakening its own hand.On December 13, US Senator Bernie Sanders decided to withdraw a War Powers Resolution on ending US support for Saudi offensive efforts in the war in Yemen. Sanders was supposed to put the resolution to a vote, believing it would have passed. However, owing to pressure mounted against him from the White House, he decided to retreat. Instead, the progressive American senator claimed that he was informed that the Biden administration would â€œcontinue workingâ€ with his office on ending the conflict.As revealedby The Intercept, which obtained the key talking points distributed by the White House against the resolution, the Biden administration communicated its position that such a resolution would be counterproductive and further exacerbate the crisis in Yemen. However, the â€˜Quincy Institute for Responsible Statecraftâ€™ says that Sandersâ€™ decision to withdraw the resolution â€œmay embolden the many members of Washingtonâ€™s foreign policy elite who would like to ensure that the presidentâ€™s capability to unilaterally wage war remains unchallenged by Congressâ€™s constitutional prerogative over matters of war and peace.â€The biggest problem here for the US government is that the War Powers Resolution essentially aims to force Biden to implement most of the policies that he himself outlined in February of 2021. Despite Biden having announced that the US was halting all â€œrelevant arms salesâ€ to the Saudi-led coalition â€“ which has been at war with Yemenâ€™s Ansarallah, known commonly as the Houthis, since 2015 â€“ this policy position has never been put into practice.Read moreYemen conflict may flare up again, US warnsDuring his 2020 campaign, Biden claimed that he would make longtime American ally Saudi Arabia a global â€œpariah.â€Yet, when it began to sink in that the powerful oil-producing state was a necessary partner in the Middle East, a realization that came months into the West's sanctions campaign aimed at Russia, the Biden administration quickly decided to change its stance. In July, the president decidedto go on a foreign visit to Saudi Arabia, while in the days prior he entered into discussions about beginning to supply the Saudis with offensive weapons again; the framing of this was a little disingenuous because the weapons sales freeze of February 2021 had effectively been ended by Aprilof the same year anyway. Both of these moves came as a clear attempt to get Saudi Arabia to raise oil-production levels, a goal that failed as the Saudi Crown Prince, Mohammed Bin Salman, refused to pander to the US president.Since then, the US government approveda potential multibillion-dollar deal with Saudi Arabia and the UAE, and in August the Biden administration grantedthe Saudi Crown Prince immunity from a civil lawsuit over his role in the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. Biden was reportedly humiliated earlier this year after allegedly bringing up the Khashoggi killing to the Crown Prince, who fired back by citing the Israeli killing of Palestinian-American journalist Shireen Abu Akleh, asking why Jamal Khashoggi mattered more. Notably, the US head of state failed a number of times to even pronounce Shireen Abu Aklehâ€™s name correctly when delivering a speech beside Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas just days earlier and did not bring the killing up to Israeli representatives.The White House insinuated, in its opposition to Senator Bernie Sandersâ€™ resolution on Yemen, that it had a hand in the six-month long ceasefirebetween the two primary opposing sides in the war. The reality was that it was the United Nations that brokered the ceasefire, which ended on October 2. In the eyes of Ansarallah, the US government is the primary obstacle to peace in Yemen; Abd al-Wahhab al-Mahbashi, a senior member of Ansarallah, recently warnedthat â€œthe presence of US troops in the Bab al-Mandab and off the coast of Yemen poses a serious threat to maritime navigation.â€ In fact, Ansarallah views the conflict as a war on behalf of the US, with Saudi Arabia acting as its proxy, a view held by millions in the region.The day following Sandersâ€™ withdrawal of his War Powers Resolution, two fuel shipments, carrying tons of diesel, were seized by the Saudi-led coalition and prevented from reaching Yemen. The blockade of Yemen is one of the major factors contributing to the resurgence of tensions â€“ Ansarallah accuses Riyadh and Abu Dhabi of stealing the nationâ€™s oil resources and depriving native Yemenis. In addition to this, when the US is clearly attempting to cozy up to Saudi Arabia, this signals to the leadership of Ansarallah that the Biden administration is favoring Riyadh in the conflict.Read moreUN brokers extension of Yemen ceasefireThe Biden administration has so far proven ineffective at bringing the Saudis under its wing in the way it had hoped, indicating that its foreign policy tactics have proven ineffective at best. The reason for this failure likely comes down to the way the current government has dealt not only with Saudi Arabia, but with all the states of the Arabian Peninsula in addition to Iran. The US has shown that it cannot be trusted to keep its word, as was proven by its Iran nuclear deal blunder. More importantly, Saudi Arabia understands that, when it comes to security, Washington is not the most important player anymore. Instead of following the Biden administration into a dangerous anti-Iran coalition, the Saudis would be a lot smarter to engage diplomatically with Tehran, a step that would be especially helpful when it comes to regional security.For Washington, meanwhile, an escalation in Yemen at this point would prove advantageous, for it could end up pushing Saudi Arabia closer to it, as the latter needs US help to maintain its war effort, although there is a chance that large-scale ballistic and cruise missile strikes against Saudi Arabiaâ€™s vital infrastructure could cause the Kingdom to go straight to the negotiating table. Regardless of how things go, it is clear that US influence in the Arabian Peninsula is rapidly declining and part of its legacy will be this brutal war that has cost upwards of 400,000 lives and that the Biden administration has refused to end.The statements, views and opinions expressed in this column are solely those of the author and do not necessarily represent those of RT.oped

title: Pentagon makes Iran nuclear prediction â€” RT World News
article: Pentagon makes Iran nuclear prediction                        Tehranâ€™s â€œbreakthrough timeâ€ has shrunk to less than two weeks, according to a US official            FILE PHOTO Â©                Atomic Energy Organization of Iran via APIran would need just 12 days to make enough uranium for an atomic bomb, the Pentagonâ€™s top policy official told Congress on Tuesday. Under Secretary of Defense for Policy Colin Kahl was asked about the defunct nuclear deal with Iran while testifying at a House Armed Services Committee hearing about arming Ukraine.â€œIranâ€™s nuclear progress since we left the JCPOA has been remarkable,â€ Kahl said, referring to the 2015 agreement by its acronym. â€œBack in 2018, when the previous administration decided to leave the JCPOA it would have taken Iran about 12 months to produce one bombâ€™s worth of fissile material. Now it would take about 12 days.â€According to a â€œconfidentialâ€ IAEA report, seen by the Associated Press on Tuesday, inspectors from the United Nations nuclear watchdog had allegedly discovered traces of uranium â€œparticlesâ€ enriched up to 83.7% in Iranâ€™s underground Fordo nuclear site. However, they found no signs of Tehran actually stockpiling it â€“ in line with explanations from Iranian officials. Behrouz Kamalvandi, spokesman for the Atomic Energy Organization of Iran (AEOI), previously dismissed a similar report by Bloomberg as â€œslander and a distortion of the facts.â€: Iran reacts to uranium claimWhile US officials and media claim Iran may be on the cusp of producing enough fissile material for a nuclear weapon, the Pentagon reportedly doesnâ€™t believe Tehran has the technology to actually build one.The agreement, officially known as the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA), placed severe restrictions on Tehranâ€™s nuclear program in exchange for lifting the UN sanctions. It was signed by Iran, China, Russia, the US, France, Germany, the United Kingdom and the EU. In May 2018, however, US President Donald Trump withdrew from the agreement and reimposed sanctions unilaterally. Iran responded by continuing the program, which Tehran has described as entirely peaceful.The Joe Biden administration has attempted to revive the deal, but has been unwilling to lift the sanctions or provide Iran with guarantees it would not violate the agreement again. Negotiations have been stalled since August 2022.: Iranian FM reveals nuclear 'signals' from USâ€œI think there is still the view that if you could resolve this issue diplomatically and put constraints back on their nuclear program, it is better than the other options,â€ Kahl told lawmakers on Tuesday. â€œBut right now, the JCPOA is on ice.â€On Sunday, Iranian Foreign Minister Hossein Amir-Abdollahian said that the US had sent a message via the Iraqi foreign minister that Washington was â€œready to conclude an agreement.â€ Iran was willing as well, so long as any settlement respected the Islamic Republicâ€™s â€œred lines,â€ said Amir-Abdollahian, notingagain that it was the US that reneged on the deal.

title: UK responds to Russian accusation over Nord Stream â€” RT World News
article: UK responds to Russian accusation over Nord Stream                        London denies it was behind the pipeline sabotage, dismissing Moscow's claim as an â€œinvented storyâ€            FILE PHOTO. Danish Defense shows the gas leaking at Nord Stream 2 seen from the Danish F-16 interceptor on Bornholm, Denmark on September 27, 2022. Â©                Danish DefenceAnadolu Agency via Getty ImagesThe United Kingdom has rebuffed a Russian accusation that it orchestrated an attack on the Nord Stream pipelines in the Baltic Sea. The statement came hours after Moscow claimed that the Royal Navy was involved in the explosions.Writing on Twitter on Saturday, the UK Ministry of Defence claimed that Moscow â€œis resorting to peddling false claims of an epic scaleâ€ in an effort to detract the global community from â€œtheir disastrous handling of the illegal invasion of Ukraine.â€The ministry went on to denounce the accusation as an â€œinvented storyâ€ which â€œsays more about arguments going on inside the Russian Government than it does about the West.â€Meanwhile Maria Zakharova, the Russian Foreign Ministry spokeswoman, has signaled that Moscow intends to draw the attention of global community and the UN Security Council to â€œa series of terrorist attacks against Russia in the Black and Baltic Seasâ€ and to Britainâ€™s involvement in the matter.Read moreBritish navy involved in Nord Stream 2 'terrorist attack' â€“ RussiaEarlier on Saturday, the Russian Defense Ministry alleged that Royal Navy operatives â€œtook part in planning, supporting and implementingâ€ the plot to destroy the key Nord Stream gas pipelines. It did not provide any direct evidence to support its assertion.The Russian Foreign Ministry earlier claimed that NATO conducted a military exercise during the summer which featured the intensive use of â€œdeep-sea equipmentâ€™â€™ close to the location where the undersea explosions occurred.The pipelines, which were built to deliver Russian natural gas directly to Germany, lost pressure abruptly on September 26, following a series of underwater explosions off the Danish island of Bornholm.

title: Soros compares Ukrainian conflict to siege of Nazi-held city â€” RT World News
article: Soros compares Ukrainian conflict to siege of Nazi-held city                        The billionaire has appeared to liken the Russian military operation in Ukraine to the 1944 siege of Budapest            Â© Getty Images  Laszlo Balogh Billionaire investor and major political donor George Soros appeared to inadvertently drew parallels between the Nazis and the modern Ukrainian military in a blog post, in which he compared the current conflict to the 1944 siege of Nazi-held Budapest by the Soviet army.In the post published on his website on Saturday, Soros called on the world to â€œstand with Ukraine, as they stand with usâ€ before finding apparent similarities between the Russian military action in Ukraine and the the siege of Budapest, then a Nazi-held city, by the Soviet forces.â€œBrave Ukrainians are now on the frontline and risking their lives in an onslaught that reminds me of the siege of Budapest in 1944 and the siege of Sarajevo in 1993,â€ the billionaire noted.The message also appeared on Sorosâ€™s Twitter account, but was later removed after some of the users pointed to the uncanny parallels. The blog post is still accessible on Sorosâ€™ site as of Monday morning.â€œIt is important that both the transatlantic alliance (the United States, Canada, the European Union, and the United Kingdom) but also other nations do whatever is in their power to support Ukraine in its time of existential threat,â€ the Open Society Foundations founder wrote, accusing Russian President Vladimir Putin of ordering â€œa direct attack on the sovereignty of all States that were once in the Soviet Union, and beyond.â€The 1944 siege of Budapest saw the Hungarian city, at the time occupied by the Nazi military, surrounded by Soviet troops for months of grueling house-to-house combat. Soros, then 14, and of Jewish origin, later claimed that he was able to survive the Nazi occupation of his city only because his family managed to obtain Christian IDs.Ordering a â€œspecial military operationâ€ in Donbass, Russian President Vladimir Putin described Russiaâ€™s mission in the country as one of â€œde-Nazificationâ€ and â€œdemilitarizationâ€. The Ukrainian military is widely reported, including by the western media, to include far-right â€œvolunteersâ€ such as the Azov Battalion, who were seen sporting Nazi regalia on multiple occasions.Read moreâ€˜Heroesâ€™: Budapest lauds Hungarians who allied with Nazis to invade USSRFacebook last week reversed its 2019 ban on praise for the far-right paramilitary force which is now embedded with the Ukrainian National Guard. The social media giant, however, said that the battalion would still be banned from posting or recruiting on Facebook.While the Kremlin has accused Kiev of perpetrating genocide against the population of Donbass, Kiev countered that claim, insisting that Russia used it as a false pretext to launch a military offensive. In its appeal to The International Court of Justice on Sunday, Ukraine accused Russia of â€œplanning acts of genocideâ€ against Ukrainians. It fell short of providing any concrete evidence of the alleged war crime.

title: 'Her Majesty's Russia Unit': How British spies have launched a full-scale propaganda war to demonize Moscow â€” RT World News
article: 'Her Majesty's Russia Unit': How British spies have launched a full-scale propaganda war to demonize Moscow                        Britain's international information war strategy was developed years ago            ByRT Russian's investigative unitÂ© Getty Images  Jack Taylor The growing political feud between Russia and the West has spurred the activation of specialized propaganda and intelligence units. With regards to the Ukraine crisis, experts say one of the most active parties has been the United Kingdom, which in recent years has stepped up its efforts todemonizeRussia by waging a full-scale propaganda war.As an RT analysis has shown, Britainâ€™s 'HMG Russia Unit,' an interdepartmental government organization created several years ago, has acted as a front for soft influence operations against Moscow with the assistance of international consulting organizations.Up until now, the activities of the operation had not been publicly visible. However,last monthpublications containing its employeesâ€™ personal information appeared in a number of Russian Telegram channels. It is alleged that the email addresses included in these posts belong to employees of the HMG Russia Unit who are also connected to various other UK government departments, including the Cabinet Office, the Foreign and Commonwealth Office, military intelligence, MI5, and the Ministry of Defence, as well as American curators attached to the group.Prioritized propagandaTo begin with, letâ€™s explain how a group specifically targeting Russia appeared within the British government, what its purpose is, and what it does.Read moreUK targets Russian stock marketâ€œThe government has long recognized the presence of a sustained and significant threat from Russia to the UK and its allies, including both conventional military capabilities and disinformation, illegal financial transactions, influence operations, and cyber-attacks,â€ said a report submitted to parliament by the Office of the British Prime Minister in 2020.For the British government, Russia has become â€œone of the main priorities from the point of view of national security,â€ it adds.â€œThis is why in 2017 the Government implemented the NSC-endorsed (National Security Council â€” RT) Russia Strategy, and in 2017 established the cross-Government Russia Unit which brings together the UKâ€™s diplomatic, intelligence and military capabilities to maximum effect,â€ the report goes on to say.According to the British governmentâ€™s own reports, the HMG Russia Unit, which was formally attached to the UK Foreign Office, was primarily tasked with coordinating information and propaganda campaigns aimed against Russia. This can be traced from data released by the British government and, in particular, from a large-scale program financed by the UK Conflict, Stability and Security Fund (CSSF) that was carried out by the Foreign Office up until 2021 to develop media resources, including in Russian, and so-called "counter disinformation."The program notes that the United Kingdom is working with a number of partners to improve the quality of public and independent media resources, including Russian-speaking ones, so they can â€œsupport social cohesion, uphold universal values and provide communities in countries across Eastern Europe with access to reliable information.â€The forms of support vary. They include, for example, mentoring by British media staff, consultations on creating broadcast networks, financing of joint productions, and support for regional media projects in Russian.â€œIn the coming year we will be investing over Â£8m in supporting public service and independent media. This will include projects in the Baltic States and Ukraine, as well as regional initiatives,â€ according to a document published by the UK government.Contract for demonizationHowever, the HMG Russia Unitâ€™s efforts are not limited to coordinating propaganda efforts. From data on the UK governmentâ€™s public procurement portal, it can be seen that it has served as a customer for the Green Finance initiative â€“ a British-Russian project aimed at promoting sustainable financing for developing institutional ties between Moscow and London in the environmental and economic spheres. The final date for fulfilling the contract is March 31, 2022.Funds in the amount of Â£987,600 were received by the well-known consulting company PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP (PwC).If we analyze the UK governmentâ€™s funding allocations targeting Russia, it turns out that in addition to PwC, Moodyâ€™s Analytics (a Moodyâ€™s subsidiary) received funds through a specialized non-profit entity named UK Research and Innovation as part of a contract to track companies and individuals that have been sanctioned over the Ukraine conflict. The relevant restrictions are noted on a portal for the placement of UK government contracts.Read moreEU calls for confiscation of frozen Russian assetsThe involvement of private international consulting companies in promoting the UK agenda with respect to Russia, as well as the post-Soviet space, logically correlates with the HMG Russia Unitâ€™s involvement in large-scale projects to demonize Russiaâ€™s image.In this regard, there is a noteworthy letter dated February 7, 2019, addressed to the British investigative journalist Till Bruckner, who had requested data on the activities of the Integrity Initiative from the British Foreign Office. It states that in 2017-2018, Â£296,500 was earmarked to finance the project, and an additional Â£1.961 million in 2019.A response to the journalistâ€™s request was received from the HMG Russia Unit. The Integrity Initiative has been flagged as one of Britainâ€™s main programs responsible for spreading anti-Russia fakes and waging a propaganda war against Moscow. At the same time, as RT noted back in 2018,the hacker collectiveAnonymouspublished internal documents from the Integrity Initiative that revealed the mechanisms British media networks employ in their subversive work aimed at Russia.â€˜Fakeâ€™ trendsettersBritish influence networks initially set a certain standard for the Westâ€™s anti-Russian template, Alexey Martynov, a political scientist who heads the Institute of Newly Established States, said in an interview with RT.â€œThe British are trendsetters, in a sense. The now popular buzzword â€˜fake newsâ€™, the formation of false narratives, the management of media streams â€“ all this was born in their heads,â€ says the political scientist. â€œGoebbels studied with British military propagandists. What they are doing is military propaganda.â€The academic noted that using private consulting companies and rating agencies as tools to influence Russia was a â€˜soft powerâ€™ tactic traditionally employed by specialized British agencies.â€œAny rating agency is created as a tool for manipulating media flows, and other business dimensions grow out of this. They also have access to domestic statistics that are not available to the public,â€ the political scientist said. â€œThese mechanisms have been tested since the 1990s, when all data was opened to foreign â€˜partnersâ€™. Then these mechanisms were created â€“ it is important to have a high ranking with rating agencies, otherwise you wonâ€™t receive loans.â€The UK continues to ramp up its sanctions against Russia. In May, it announced another package of restrictive measures, adding more individuals and legal entities from Russia to the list and planning to ban imports of Russian oil. In April, London also banned the import of Russian silver, caviar, and wood products.ANALYSIS

title: UK bars Russian ships from its ports â€” RT World News
article: UK bars Russian ships from its ports                        The ban will affect billions of pounds worth of Russian imports            FILE PHOTO: An oil and chemical tanker offloads fuels at Plymouth, Britain, July 20, 2021 Â© Getty Images  Peter Titmuss The British Department for Transport on Monday banned all Russian ships from its ports. This latest economic penalty, imposed following Russiaâ€™s military offensive in Ukraine, will likely stop more than Â£8 billion ($10.7 billion) worth of Russian imports from reaching the UK when combined with other measures.In a statement, the Department for Transport said that UK ports are being asked to deny access to any ships believed to be â€œowned, controlled, chartered or operated by any person connected with Russiaâ€ or connected with sanctioned individuals, vessels flying the Russian flag, or vessels registered in Russia.UK blocking ports to ships owned, controlled, chartered or operated by any person connected with Russia. Simple, broad, effective. pic.twitter.comt3Fhkl0BIaâ€” Matthew Caruana Galizia (@mcaruanagalizia) February 28, 2022â€œFurther detailed sanctions against Russian shipping are being developed,â€ the statement concluded.Britain imported Â£8.3 billion worth of Russian goods in the first three quarters of 2021, mostly oil, metal, and gas products. With Russian ships now banned from British ports, and British airspace off limits to Russian flights, it is likely that most of these imports will grind to a halt.In recent days, the UK has also sanctioned Russian banks, including the countryâ€™s central bank, and backed Russiaâ€™s expulsion from the SWIFT banking network. Meanwhile, London has shipped anti-tank missiles and other â€œlethal aidâ€ to Ukraine.Speaking in Parliament on Monday, UK Home Secretary Liz Truss said that the British government wants "a situation where they [Russia] can't access their funds, their trade can't flow, their ships can't dock and their planes can't land.â€Russia has banned British flights from its airspace, and may nationalize the property of foreigners in Russia, Russian Security Council Deputy Chairman Dmitry Medvedev stated on Saturday.

title: UK candidatesâ€™ militancy and imperialism threaten to bring Britain down â€” RT World News
article: UK candidatesâ€™ militancy and imperialism threaten to bring Britain down                        Confronting Russia and China has become the main talking point as Rishi Sunak and Liz Truss try to â€˜out-hawkâ€™ each other            ByTimur Fomenko, a political analystConservative leadership candidates Rishi Sunak and Liz Truss during Britain's Next Prime Minister: The ITV Debate at Riverside Studios on July 17, 2022 in London, England. Â© Jonathan Hordle  ITV via Getty Images During the upcoming televised debate, British Conservative leadership candidate Rishi Sunak, who served as Chancellor of the Exchequer under Boris Johnsonâ€™s government, is expectedto promise resolute action against China, which he accuses of â€œbeing the biggest long-term threat to the UK.â€Claiming that Beijing is now â€œinfiltrating our universitiesâ€ and â€œstealing our technology,â€ racist scaremongering talking points which originated from the Trump administration, Sunak will call for strengthening NATO cooperation against China and will pledge to close all 30 Confucius institutes in the country (which teach Chinese language but have been frequently and baselessly accused of espionage and political interference).To most Tory hawks, however, Sunakâ€™s rhetoric isnâ€™t convincing. Only as recently as January did he in fact vow to deepen business ties between China and the UK. His change of course is blatantly motivated by his desire to become the leader of the party and pander to a right-wing populist base who overwhelmingly favour his opponent Liz Truss, who models herself quite explicitly after Margaret Thatcher. As the first ever ethnic minority candidate for Conservative leadership, it isnâ€™t rocket science to see why he is at a disadvantage in such circumstances, a sad but uncomfortable truth.Read moreLiz Truss warns the world of evil womenWith Sunakâ€™s previous positions on China also being fairly reasonable, this has also quickly turned into a line of attack against him by the right-wing press, with the Daily Mail recently claiming he was supported by Chinaâ€™s Global Times, which, it said, was â€œthe endorsement nobody wanted.â€However, nobody would seriously think that Sunak is going to â€˜out-hawkâ€™ Truss, who has been fanatical in her confrontational approach to diplomacy against both China and Russia, and her zealous obsession with democracy â€“ or rather, the rhetoric construct of â€œdemocracyâ€ so often used as a rallying cry by Western leaders.For Britain as a whole, this is disastrous news, but few people will be realizing it. Despite talk of â€œglobal Britainâ€ and â€œfree trade,â€ whoever should succeed Boris Johnson (and it will probably be Truss) will put Britain on a collision course with the worldâ€™s second-largest economy, the largest in terms of imports and exports, despite the lingering impacts of Brexit, and of course whilst simultaneously pursuing an aggressive proxy war in Ukraine, where Truss wants nothing less than the defeat of the Russian state. One might pause and ask, what on Earth has gone wrong with British foreign policy? In light of all this, and of Brexit, how could it have become so unhinged and self-defeating? It is demonstrative of the sheer madness which has captured the political mainstream in the light of Brexit.Modern Britain has always, at every point in history, been arrogant and aggressive, completely unrepentant of its imperial legacy. Attributing Brexit as the starting point of such unbridled chauvinism might lead one to forget about the destruction of Iraq, Libya and Syria, and of course Britainâ€™s continuing toadyism to American foreign-policy preferences and clear lack of independence in its own direction. After all, the United Kingdom has on paper participated in every single US-led war after World War II. The sole exception was Vietnam, thanks to Harold Wilson, a Labour Prime Minister who truly defined the â€œswinging sixtiesâ€ in Britain and refused to assist. But he was the exception.Read moreThree candidates remain in race to replace JohnsonThus, whilst it was always there, Brexit has manifested itself as probably the highest and most chauvinistic form of Anglophone exceptionalism and ideological elitism yet, specifically because it has suffocated the post-war debate concerning Britainâ€™s post-imperial identity and the bid to be part of Europe. Instead of moving on from the past, it has doubled down on it, and in turn has merged with a brand of extreme neoconservatism to become even more subservient to the United States and wage hyper-aggression against certain countries, in this case Russia and China, in the name of British civilisation. Any pragmatism, any reason, balance and humility that might have otherwise restrained Conservative politicians has evaporated in the name of populism.Now weâ€™re at the stage where an Indian-origin British politician feels he can solicit political gain for himself by weaponizing fear, hate and scaremongering against Chinese people, betraying the diverse and open country where his parents settled and which allowed him to become so successful. It is a sorry state of affairs, and this aggressive pursuit of burning bridges and geopolitical confrontation will undoubtedly, as it has already, place further strain on the British economy, already beset by surging inflation, shrinking incomes, growing industrial unrest and eye-watering inequality. While of course, Liz Truss looks to be an almost inevitable victor, the fact someone like her is in this position speaks volumes about not her ascent, but about Britainâ€™s descent. If you thought Boris Johnson was bad (he was personally incompetent but politically restrained by the standards of others), things are about to get a whole lot worse. On multiple fronts, weâ€™re going to see the UK now take the deep turn of right-wing regression the US has been experiencing.The statements, views and opinions expressed in this column are solely those of the author and do not necessarily represent those of RT.oped

title: Israeli military drone maker hacked â€” RT World News
article: Israeli military drone maker hacked                        An â€œunknown actorâ€ was behind the data breach, according to a US-based branch of Israelâ€™s Elbit Systems            FILE PHOTO: The Elbit Systems Hermes 900 Kochav ("Star") UAV Â©                Elbit SystemsAn Israeli arms contractor specializing in unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) has fallen victim to a hack that impacted nearly 400 employees, the company said, noting that sensitive personal data was likely stolen from its US branch, Elbit America.The firm announced the cyber attack in a notification to authorities in Maine earlier this month, as was first reported by TechCrunch on Monday, revealing that 369 staffers were swept up in a hack that occurred in June.â€œOn June 8, 2022, someone attempted to interfere with Elbit Americaâ€™s cyber operations. We immediately shut down our network and took steps to secure our environment,â€ the company said in a letter to those potentially affected by the breach.After hiring a â€œleading cybersecurity firmâ€ to investigate, Elbit said it determined that â€œan unknown actor gained access to and obtained certain dataâ€ from its network, including â€œindividualsâ€™ names, addresses, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, direct deposit information, and ethnicity.â€The company offered few other details about the cyber intrusion, but said it did not believe any personal information had been â€œmisused as a result of this incident.â€: Israel sells air defense system to Arab country â€“ mediaThe Texas-based subsidiary did not name any actors believed to have carried out the hack, though cybersecurity blogger Eduard Kovacs observed that a ransomware gang known as â€˜Black Bastaâ€™ boasted of an attack on Elbit Systems in late June, not long after the company says it was breached. The group reportedly posted a handful of stolen documents on its website at the time, including payroll information and a non-disclosure agreement.Headquartered in Haifa, Israel, Elbitâ€™s main business primarily offers drone technology, though it has also dabbled in the surveillance industry through a number of acquisitions. According to an investigation by researchers at Citizen Lab, an Elbit subsidiary known as Cyberbit produced spyware used to surveil Ethiopian dissidents in the US, the UK and elsewhere for some time starting in 2016. Elbit later sold most of its shares in Cyberbit and became a minority stakeholder by 2020.: Iran provides details on new suicide droneElbit has come under fire from human rights organizations not only for the Cyberbit controversy, but for its broader role in supplying the Israeli military with attack, reconnaissance and spy drones. In July, activists targeted a factory producing UAV engines for Elbit based in Shenstone, Britain, claiming to inflict thousands of dollars in damage to the facility in retaliation for lethal Israeli raids in the occupied West Bank. In addition to Israelâ€™s own armed forces, Elbit has sold drone tech to a long list of countries, including the United States, Azerbaijan, Brazil, the United Kingdom, Colombia, Georgia and the Philippines, among others.

title: The â€˜garden versus jungleâ€™ worldview of the EUâ€™s top diplomat is not only racist, itâ€™s delusional â€” RT World News
article: The â€˜garden versus jungleâ€™ worldview of the EUâ€™s top diplomat is not only racist, itâ€™s delusional                        Josep Borrellâ€™s neocolonial comparison fails to notice the Westâ€™s decline, caused by elites like him            Graham Hryce isan Australian journalist and former media lawyer, whose work has been published in The Australian, the Sydney Morning Herald, the Age, the Sunday Mail, the Spectator and Quadrant.Graham Hryce isan Australian journalist and former media lawyer, whose work has been published in The Australian, the Sydney Morning Herald, the Age, the Sunday Mail, the Spectator and Quadrant.EU High Representative for Foreign Affairs Josep Borrell. Â©                Russian Foreign MinistryHandoutAnadolu Agency via Getty ImagesJosep Borrell, the European Unionâ€™s foreign policy and security chief, gave an important speech to the European Diplomatic Academy in Bruges, Belgium in mid-October.Being amongst fellow members of the global elites, Borrell felt able to set out his views on the relationship between Europe and the West and other nations with an unusual degree of honesty and candour.â€œEurope is a gardenâ€ declared Borrell. â€œWe have built a garden. Everything works. It is the best combination of political freedom, economic prosperity and social cohesion that the humankind has been able to build â€“ the three things together.â€But, warned Borrell ominously, â€œThe rest of the world is not exactly a garden. Most of the rest of the world is a jungle, and the jungle could invade the garden.â€How then was this unwelcome prospect to be avoided?The solution was simple, according to Borrell â€“ EU ambassadors, who he designated as â€œgardeners,â€ had to â€œgo to the jungleâ€ and impose on it the ideological, political, and economic agendas of the globalised West.The â€œgardenâ€ could not sit by idly and do nothing, cautioned Borrell. â€œA nice small garden surrounded by high walls in order to prevent the jungle from coming in is not going to be a solution. Because the jungle has a strong growth capacity, the wall will never be high enough in order to protect the garden,â€ Borrell explained.â€œEuropeans have to be much more engaged with the rest of the world otherwise the rest of the world will invade us by different ways and means,â€ Borrell advised.Borrellâ€™s speech was immediately criticised by a few left-wing politicians in Europe, as well as some non-European states, most notably the UAE, on the grounds that it was â€œracistâ€ and â€œrooted in colonialism.â€Those criticisms are valid as far as they go, and Borrell grudgingly offered an apology of sorts â€“ saying â€œI am sorry if some have felt offended.â€ Nevertheless, he stood by his basic metaphor, reiterating that â€œRegrettably, the world in which we live today looks more and more like a â€˜jungleâ€™ and less and less like a â€˜gardenâ€™.â€Read moreEU's top diplomat apologizes for â€˜jungleâ€™ remarksBut much more serious criticisms can be legitimately levelled at Borrellâ€™s crass worldview â€“ censures that go well beyond the obvious fact that it simply reeks of nineteenth century Euro-centric prejudices.First, let us start with Borrellâ€™s extraordinary Pollyanna-like assertion that in Europe and the West â€œeverything worksâ€ and that the â€œgardenâ€ nations are havens of political, economic, and social stability.This pronouncement will no doubt have come as a surprise to many citizens in Europe and the West.Has Borrell not noticed the recent rise of powerful right-wing political movements in a number of European countries? Is he not aware of the recent election results in Italy and Sweden?Have Borrellâ€™s advisors not informed him of the political instability that has engulfed the United Kingdom in recent months, let alone the crisis in democracy that has crippled the United States for the past two years?Has Borrell not noticed the dramatic recent rise in energy prices; rising inflation; rising interest rates; long-term wage stagnation; and the looming economic recession that is predicted to engulf many Western nations in the near future?
