The US also sought for the PA to pause its attempts to take Israel before the International Court of Justice and the UN for alleged war crimes â€“ a move for which the PA has been punished with Israeli sanctions.Last Thursday, CIA director Bill Burns expressed his concern over the possibility of a â€˜third intifadaâ€™ [Palestinian uprising] erupting inside the West Bank, stating that â€œa lot of what weâ€™re seeing today has a very unhappy resemblance to some of those realities that we saw then [during the Second Intifada] tooâ€. His concern is congruent with the reality on the ground, where last year was the deadliest for West Bank Palestinians since the end of the Second Intifada in 2005, according to the United Nations. Palestinian attacks against Israeli settlers and soldiers are also a daily occurrence now.Read moreDeadly attack near Jerusalem is â€˜terrorismâ€™ â€“ NetanyahuTwo-state solution blockedDespite the US government clearly identifying the nature of the escalation, it shows complete ignorance of its own role in creating the current hostilities. The bulk of the US secretary of stateâ€™s visit to Palestine-Israel was tailored to forwarding Arab-Israeli normalization efforts and to expanding the â€˜Negev Forumâ€™, which Morocco, the UAE, Bahrain and Egypt form with Israel, in order to advance their own ties. At the same time, Antony Blinken spoke of reaching a â€œtwo-state solutionâ€ between Palestinians and Israelis as being the only path to any lasting peace.Under the Arab Peace Initiative of 2002 (also known as the Saudi Initiative), a â€œtwo-state solutionâ€ (meaning the recognition by Israel of a Palestinian state and the end of occupation of Palestinian territories) is a precondition for the normalization of ties between Israel and Arab states. By pushing for normalization without that precondition, Blinken effectively seeks to deprive the Palestinian Authority of its best bargaining chip and leaves it powerless to extract any concessions from the Israeli government, whose officials will not even consider sitting down for meetings with their Palestinian counterparts.Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has already stated that he is not willing to halt settlement expansion, as proposed by the US government, with Israelâ€™s Finance Minister, Bezalel Smotrich, openly announcing that there will be no freeze on settlement construction, which is considered illegal by the UN and most world powers. Israel has also announced its intention to increase raids and further military activities in the West Bank, in what it deems to be a preparation for likely hostilities during the Muslim Holy month of Ramadan.Hope for Palestinians is the only way to peaceDespite the PA having announced the end of its security coordination with Israel, it is clear that some coordination is still occurring and that the announcement was more of a public relations move for President Abbas, who is feeling the pressure from a disgruntled Palestinian population. This in itself is a key indicator that the PA is feeling the pressure from Palestinian society at large and a sign that any US-trained PA force to combat the militia groups could lead to a disaster, whereby the Ramallah-based authority could even be overthrown due to the outrage such a step would cause. When the CIA worked to create the â€œnew PA security forceâ€ during the latter years of the Second Intifada, it only worked after the PA itself had participated in the fight against the Israeli military and still maintained some degree of popular support. In addition to this, the Israeli army had conducted â€˜Operation Defensive Shield,â€™ which led to the assassinations or arrests of the most prominent militia leaders inside the West Bank.Read morePalestinians killed in West Bank raidThe only way the PA could possibly regain control of Jenin and Nablus is by proving to the Palestinian people that it is on their side, and not fighting for the US and Israel. It is also the reality that many of the leading fighters in the militia groups, especially in Jenin, are actually members of the PAâ€™s security forces that have gone rogue. Armed militias also seem to be forming in areas like Bethlehem, al-Khalil and even Jericho, which proves that the re-emergence of the armed struggle in the West Bank is not only limited to the north of the territory.The only way to properly combat the escalation and to stop this from growing into a much larger confrontation, is to provide hope for the Palestinian people inside the West Bank, something that the US will not even consider. Instead of the US working as an objective mediator, it works solely for Israelâ€™s immediate interests and accepts the political restraints of each Israeli government as an excuse for repeatedly violating its own red lines. The US considers every single Palestinian political party as a terrorist organization, other than the mainstream branch of the Fatah Party, meaning that they will not even talk to any Palestinian representatives other than those that adhere to their own demands. The obsessive pursuit of Saudi Arabia normalizing ties with Israel, seemingly for political gain on behalf of the Biden administration, also contributes to robbing Palestinians of any hope for peace.The situation inside the West Bank cannot be resolved using bombs and bullets. Even if every single member of all the armed groups were to be killed, the same problem would again emerge for Israel in the future. Despite this, Washington will never look critically at what is going on and realize that there are two sides to this conflict. At this time the US government is dealing with the escalation as if Israel has a termite problem and not that there are people who are rising up in an ongoing struggle for statehood.The statements, views and opinions expressed in this column are solely those of the author and do not necessarily represent those of RT.oped

title: UK mulls spy-balloon fleet of its own â€” RT World News
article: UK mulls spy-balloon fleet of its own                        The project is aimed at giving London and its NATO allies â€˜an advantage over adversariesâ€™            Â©                Gareth Cattermole  Getty ImagesThe UK government is researching the possibility of creating its own high-altitude surveillance airships, according to the March issue of Desider, a magazine produced by Britain's Ministry of Defence. This comes shortly after the scandal over a Chinese â€œspy balloonâ€ in US airspace.The UK defense ministry last year signed a Â£100 million ($118.6 million) contract to research â€œstratospheric uncrewed air systems,â€ according to The Timesâ€™ report published Monday. Britain is considering buying a fleet of spy balloons, it added.Project Aether is a research initiative that aims to â€œbetter understand the stratosphere and the high-altitude platforms that could operate there,â€ Ross Corbett, the projectâ€™s military requirements manager told Desider. The research is assigned to the British Defence Equipment and Supportâ€™s Future Capabilities Group, Londonâ€™s â€œhub for strategic research and innovation.â€â€œSuccessfully exploiting [the stratosphere] could mean huge potential benefits,â€ Corbett said. He also explained that there was still a lot of testing to be done before Britain could operate surveillance airships at 50,000 to 80,000 feet above Earth for long periods of time.The proposed â€œhigh-altitude, long-endurance unmanned air systemsâ€ could be used for â€œintelligence, surveillance, reconnaissance and rebroadcast activitiesâ€ by the UK armed forces and their NATO allies, Corbett said.Project Aether is working with the American Sierra Nevada corporation, British company Voltitude and the European joint venture Airbus, one of the leaders of the global aerospace industry. Corbett claims that the research will help the UK secure an â€œoperational advantage over our adversaries.â€Read moreUS suspects cranes of spying for China â€“ WSJThis comes after the highly-publicized scandal between Washington and Beijing in which the US accused China of flying a â€œspy balloonâ€ over American soil and downed it with a fighter jet. China blasted the US for â€œoverreactionâ€ and insisted it was a civilian airship that had blown off course.British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak said in February that he was ready to shoot down any Chinese balloons if they were spotted in UK airspace. Sunak added that he would â€œdo whatever it takes to keep our country safe.â€ Defense secretary Ben Wallace alleged in a comment to tabloid The Sun that China has â€œprobably spiedâ€ on Britain, adding that â€œsimple things like weather balloonsâ€ could be turned into sophisticated surveillance gear.

title: Beijing calls US worldâ€™s â€˜primary nuclear threatâ€™ â€” RT World News
article: Beijing calls US worldâ€™s â€˜primary nuclear threatâ€™                        Washingtonâ€™s charges against Chinaâ€™s nuclear arsenal are merely a â€œpretextâ€ to continue expanding its own, the foreign ministry has said            Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Mao Ning gestures during a press conference at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Beijing, March 1, 2023. Â©                AP  Liu ZhengThe United States is the top â€œnuclear threatâ€ in the world, China has said, accusing Washington of seeking to maintain â€œmilitary hegemonyâ€ over other nations after US officials declared the need to reign in Beijingâ€™s much smaller weapons program.Speaking to reportersduring a press briefing on Friday, Foreign Ministry spokesperson Mao Ning was asked to respond after a top security adviser to US President Joe Biden stated the White Houseneeded toâ€œinvest China in work to diminish nuclear threats.â€â€œCalling China a â€˜nuclear threatâ€™ is a convenient pretext for the US to expand its own nuclear arsenal and keep its military hegemony,â€ she said, insisting China has maintained a â€œprudent and responsibleâ€ nuclear policy, in stark contrast to Washingtonâ€™s.It is the US who is the primary source of nuclear threat in the world.Following a foreign ministerâ€™s meeting in New Delhi earlier on Friday by the four-way QUAD alliance â€“ consisting of the US, Japan, Australia and India â€“ officials also issued a statement deeming the â€œuse or threat of useâ€ of nuclear weapons â€œinadmissible.â€ Though the remark was not explicitly aimed at Beijing, the QUAD grouping, at times dubbed an â€˜Asian NATO,â€™ has frequently pointed to alleged threats posed by China in the Indo-Pacific region.: Australia vows to protect US nuclear â€˜crown jewelsâ€™â€œChina has stated our position on QUAD on multiple occasions. We believe that state-to-state cooperation needs to be consistent with the trend of peace and development,â€ rather than about creating â€œexclusionaryâ€ regional alliances, Mao continued, going on to note the upcoming nuclear technology transfer from the US to Australia under the separate AUKUS pact.â€œThe US has also built small blocs reminiscent of the Cold War by bolstering extended deterrence and conducting nuclear submarine cooperation,â€ she said.Further steps for the trilateral AUKUS agreement, which also includes the UK, are set to be revealed later this month, with officials hoping for a â€œseamless transferâ€ of nuclear propulsion technology from Washington to Canberra. Beijing has previously slammed the deal for advancing â€œnuclear proliferationâ€ around the world, given that Australia lacks its own domestic capability for the sensitive tech.

title: EU nation backs Chinese peace plan â€” RT World News
article: EU nation backs Chinese peace plan                        The ongoing conflict between Moscow and Kiev is bad for both Russia and Ukraine, as well as â€œthe whole world,â€ Budapest believes            FILE PHOTO: Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban Â©                Global Look Press  Xinhua  Attila VolgyiHungaryâ€™s government supports Beijingâ€™s peace plan for the ongoing conflict in Ukraine, Prime Minister Viktor Orban told parliament on Monday. The 12-point plan released by China last week calls for resuming peace talks and respecting the sovereignty and territorial integrity of all nations while condemning unilateral sanctions.â€œWe also consider Chinaâ€™s peace plan important and support it,â€ Orban told the lawmakers. In his half-hour-long speech, Orban insisted that the ongoing conflict was â€œbad for Ukrainians, Russians, Hungarians, Europe, and it is becoming increasingly clear [that] it is bad for the whole world.â€ The prime minister then maintained that Budapest should stay out of the conflict, as was decided through a â€œnational consultation.â€The prime minister also criticized some opposition parties for being seemingly overzealous in their support for Kiev to the point where they barely â€œdifferentiatedâ€ between Ukraine and Hungary, but said that he agreed there should be a country between Russia and Hungary. â€œWe respect the Ukrainians, we help the Ukrainians,â€ Orban said, adding, however, that â€œthe interests of Ukraine can never precede the interests of Hungary.â€He also admitted that Ukraine was likely to eventually join NATO â€œsooner or laterâ€ while arguing that the blocâ€™s further expansion to the east â€œmust be reconsidered ten thousand times.â€Read moreHungary outlines flaws with arms shipments to UkraineAt the same time, Orban supported the accession of Sweden and Finland to NATO. He also described the military bloc as a guarantor of security, while admitting that he was not enthusiastic about everything that happens within NATO.Meanwhile, Kievâ€™s backers in the West have brushed off Beijingâ€™s proposals. NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg said that China didnâ€™t â€œhave much credibilityâ€ in this issue as it refused to condemn Russiaâ€™s actions and join the Western sanctions.Moscow earlier welcomed Chinese efforts aimed at resolving the ongoing conflict through peaceful means. Last Sunday, the Kremlin said, however, that it saw no opportunity for a political resolution of the conflict at the moment.Ukrainian President Vladimir Zelensky recently maintained that there was â€œnothing to talk aboutâ€ with Russia and â€œno oneâ€ in Moscow Kiev could talk to. His words came amid reported attempts by his Western backers, including France, Germany and the UK, to encourage Ukraine to engage in talks with Russia.

title: NATO members float Ukraine negotiations plan â€“ WSJ â€” RT World News
article: NATO members float Ukraine negotiations plan â€“ WSJ                        UK, France and Germany reportedly offered weapons and security commitments as a way of starting talks with Russia            Left to right: Ukrainian President Vladimir Zelensky, French President Emmanuel Macron and German Chancellor Olaf Scholz at the Elysee Palace, February 9, 2023. Â©                Global Look PressKeystone Press AgencyNATO's three most powerful European members collectively back a plan aimed at pushing Ukraine to negotiate with Moscow, the Wall Street Journal reported on Friday. The newspaper claimed that France and Germany support the British initiative and have already advised President Vladimir Zelensky to talk, though he has refused.Under the proposals, Kiev would receive even moreWestern weapons andbe provided with security guarantees just short of NATO membership, the outlet explained, citing anonymous officials.Though French President Emmanuel Macron has publicly called for â€œa military offensive which pushes back the Russian front in order to open the way for a return to negotiations,â€ he has privately advised Zelensky to make â€œdifficult decisions,â€ according to officials who spoke to the Journal.Over dinner at the Elysee Palace earlier this month, Macron and German Chancellor Olaf Scholz told Zelensky he needed to start considering peace talks, according to people familiar with the conversation. London, Paris and Berlin would not comment on the record.â€œWe keep repeating that Russia mustnâ€™t win, but what does that mean? If the war goes on for long enough with this intensity, Ukraineâ€™s losses will become unbearable,â€ a senior French official told the Journal. â€œAnd no one believes they will be able to retrieve Crimea.â€Read moreRussia comments on Chinaâ€™s Ukraine roadmapAs a way to encourage Zelensky, the outlet said, British PM Rishi Sunak has put together a plan to give Kiev â€œbroader access to advanced military equipment, weapons and ammunition,â€ to be considered at the NATO summit in July.â€œThe NATO summit must produce a clear offer to Ukraine, also to give Zelensky a political win that he can present at home as an incentive for negotiations,â€ an unnamed British official told the outlet. If Moscow sees that the West is prepared to support Kiev even more, maybe it will be persuaded it canâ€™t achieve its military objectives, the official added.France and Germany support the initiative and see it as a way to â€œboost Ukrainian confidenceâ€ and give it an incentive to start negotiations with Russia, according to unnamed officials from both countries.Sunakâ€™s plan does not include stationing NATO forces in Ukraine or offering Kiev â€œArticle 5â€ commitments to intervene in case of an attack, the officials said. Ukrainian Deputy Foreign Minister Andrey Melnik said it was a good first step, but that Kiev needed â€œa clear commitment that it does not exclude NATO membership, which is the only solution for a lasting peace.â€On Friday, the Russian Foreign Ministry listed its conditions for the diplomatic solution of the conflict, which included the West ending its â€œsupply of weapons and mercenariesâ€ to Kiev and Ukraine returning to neutrality after being demilitarized and â€œdenazified.â€Meanwhile, NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg has said that Russia is winning the logistical war of attrition, leaving it unclear how much the US-led bloc could spare for Ukraine in terms of weapons and ammunition.Zelensky has rejected any negotiations with Moscow, saying on Friday that â€œThere is nothing to talk about and nobody to talk about over there.â€

title: EU approves new anti-Russia sanctions â€” RT World News
article: EU approves new anti-Russia sanctions                        The bloc has followed the US, the UK, Australia and New Zealand in announcing a fresh round of measures against Moscow            Â©Getty Images                  Sean GallupEU member states approved a tenth round of anti-Russia sanctions on Friday, followingother Western statesin imposing new measures to mark the one-year anniversary ofMoscowâ€™s military operation in Ukraine.The latest sanctions include tighter export restrictions on dual-use items and technology, as well as â€œmeasures against Russian disinformation,â€ according to an announcement by the Swedish Presidency of the Council of the EU. The bloc also agreed to impose fresh restrictions against individuals and entities that are deemed to be supporting the military operation, â€œspreading propaganda or delivering drones used by Russiaâ€ in Ukraine.â€œThe EU stands united with Ukraine and the Ukrainian people. We will keep supporting Ukraine, for as long as it takes,â€ the Swedish Presidency said.The statement echoed a phrase, â€œas long as it takes,â€ used by President Joe Biden and other US officials in recent days to reiterate Washingtonâ€™s support for Ukraine. And like those US leaders, the EU didnâ€™t specifically define the goal that must be reached, as long as it takes.: Exemptions in new EU anti-Russian sanctions revealedThe US, the UK, Australia and New Zealand announced their new anti-Russia sanctions earlier on Friday. EU members reportedly struggled for a third straight day to reach agreement on their new measures, at least partly because of an impasse between Poland and Italy over new restrictions on rubber imports.Despite Western leadersâ€™ insistence that these sanctions â€œare working,â€ Russiaâ€™s economy contracted by only 2.1% last year, far less severely than the 11.2% predicted by the World Bank in April. With energy revenue higher than before the conflict began, the countryâ€™s economy is predicted to grow faster than the UKâ€™s this year.The sanctions, which were meant to impose suffering on the Russian people, have backfired on Western nations, President Vladimir Putin said on Tuesday.â€œThey miscalculated, and Russiaâ€™s economy proved much more robust than the West expected,â€ he said in his annual address to the countryâ€™s lawmakers.:    US reveals more anti-Russia sanctions
